course.subject: ELEC
course.name: Stochastic Processes
course.description: Borel/sigma fields.  Sequences of random variables and convergence.  Spectral factorization.  Karhunen-Loeve Expansion.  Stationarity, ergodicity and spectral estimation.  Mean square estimation and Kalman filtering.  Entropy.  System identification.

reviews.author: Chingyu1
reviews.title: Stochastic Processes
reviews.comment_content:
Probability, multiple rv, conditional (including matrix form)
Random process (typical ee treatment)
Estimators
reviews.comment_teaching: The lecture provides good insights towards some minor points of the content for research purpose if in related field.
reviews.comment_grading:
Grading is reasonable
15% hw
35% mid term
50% final

However, comprehensive revision like an undergraduate course is required because of the exams. (The exams are moderately difficult but not extremely difficult but you must do comprehensive revision, you may lag behind the others otherwise), but sometimes rpg does not have enough time to do revision so it was more like an undergraduate course.
reviews.comment_workload:
5 homework in total, each with 2-4 problems. The workload should be treated as an undergraduate probability course.
You can anticipate the exam content (matrix & multiple rv equations for the probabiltiy part, knowing that the matrix treatment was skipped in the ug course)
For random process they are the book questions and usually the exam comes up with modified book question so you must know the book question already in order to answer the modified one in the exam (but teaching and exam content varies term by term)

reviews.author: Scipio
reviews.comment_content: The content covers much knowledge.Covers most of the knowledge of random processes, but the content is still relatively simple, if you want to understand in-depth, you need to explore by yourself
reviews.comment_teaching: Most of the time you need to learn by yourself, otherwise you don't know what the teacher is talking about.
reviews.comment_grading: Good grading. The difficulty of the exam depends on the mood of TA, it will vary greatly. I had a hard time in the exam
reviews.comment_workload: The workload is much higher since you need to complete four assignments and 2 exams.

reviews.author: tarja
reviews.comment_content:
The textbook is P. Z. Jr. Peebles, Probability, Random Variables, and Random Signal Principles, 4th ed., McGraw Hill, 2001.

As a PG course, I think the content is a bit less than I expected. As long as you have a basic knowledge about  ELEC2100 and ELEC2600 then you can take this course without any difficulties.

Lecture 1: Review of Probability Theory and Random Variables.
Lecture 2: Transformations, Random processes, Convergence.
Lecture 3: Stationary random processes, Power spectral density.
Lecture 4: Response of Linear Systems to Random Inputs.
Lecture 5: Estimation and optimal filtering.
Lecture 6: Discrete-time Wiener Filtering.
Lecture 7 & 8: Parameter Estimation
reviews.comment_teaching:
The lecture is super sleepy, while Weichuan is a good and considerate professor.

Thank god, this course does not take attendance. So if you can understand all the stuff in the lecture notes. Then just use the time wisely in other projects.
reviews.comment_grading:
As a PG course, its grading is nice.
----------------
Homework 15%
Midterm 35%
Final 50%
----------------         
Me: 88.5% Total, get A+
reviews.comment_workload: If you have a solid knowledge about probability theory and signal processing, this course has almost 0 workload. 5 assignments in total (could be finished in 1-2 hrs) and both midterm and final has just 4 questions (2 hrs).

reviews.author: az123zx123
reviews.title: Not bad
reviews.comment_content:
Some basic knowledge about stochastic processing. If you struggled with ELEC2600, this course is not recommended.
Borel/sigma fields. Sequences of random variables and convergence. Spectral factorization. Karhunen-Loeve Expansion. Stationarity, ergodicity and spectral estimation. Mean square estimation and Kalman filtering. Entropy. System identification.
reviews.comment_teaching: The professor is good. The only problem is the 3 hours lecture, and it's hard to concentrate especially in the second half of it.
reviews.comment_grading: pretty good. HW and exams are all above mean about 1 SD. Finally, get A.
reviews.comment_workload: The workload of homework is not high. But you really need some time to digest the content.

reviews.author: Chingyu
reviews.comment_content: The course does not cover too much math. Most are application. I took this course because I was recommended by others, who told me this course will help me with the PQE exams. However, from 19-20 semester, ECE department will not have a PQE exams. Instead, they will only hold a PQE thesis defend.
reviews.comment_teaching: Although the professor is diligent and he tried to teach a lot of things on the class. In addition I think he is a nice professor because he can reply emails in time. However, this course is 3 hours in the evening, and we will be sleepy quite easy. And also, there are many bugs in the slides. Therefore, most time we have to learn by ourselves.
reviews.comment_grading: The homework are fair. Exams are similar with HW. Getting A is quite easy. Perhaps for most PG courses, getting A are all easy. 22% for HW, 30%for Midterm, and 48% for Final.
reviews.comment_workload: 6 HW in total. Each with 5 problems, which are not too complex. And I guess for the PG courses, most students are busy with their research, and the professor understand this. Therefore both homework and exams are quite friendly.

reviews.author: FrankZShuai
reviews.title: Stochastic Process
reviews.comment_content: The content is about probability, signal and system, filter and estimation. It is not very hard to learn.
reviews.comment_teaching: I have no right to evaluate the teaching. Basically, I always learn by myself. Reading book, slides, do the homework.
reviews.comment_grading: No matter how good the course is, The grading is good. It seems that the A score is a little above average. And many students got A plus.
reviews.comment_workload: Only homework biweekly, midterm and final. Homework is about 2-4 questions, It may cost about a half day or a day to complete, The midterm and final are also not very hard, but you need to fully understand and utilize the theory. The workload is very small compared to other courses.
